B00004ZAV3|5.0|That the Beatles 1, released in 2000, would see the once-Fabs again top the charts, is a testament to the strength of their songs. There's nothing here not already available on other disks, but if you were a fledgling Beatles fan (are there any?) then this would be a good place to start for a taste.<br />This is a concise piece of history, from 1963-1970, and one can listen to the growth and evolution of John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr in a single sitting. Not only did they grow as musicians and songwriters, but the technology grew with them, or they forced it to grow.<br />&quot;Love Me Do&quot; kicks things off with primitive harmonica and rhythms, then there's smash after smash with &quot;She Loves You,&quot; &quot;I Want to Hold Your Hand,&quot; &quot;Can't Buy Me Love,&quot; &quot;A Hard Day's Night,&quot; &quot;I Feel Fine&quot; and Beatlemania in full bloom. This disk just doesn't let up. It keeps right on going with &quot;Help!&quot; &quot;Eleanor Rigby,&quot; &quot;All You Need is Love,&quot; &quot;Hey Jude,&quot; &quot;Something,&quot; &quot;Come Together,&quot; and &quot;Let it Be.&quot; What other artist can boast a hits package of 27 cuts with no filler? My criticism would be that this isn't even a definitive set, and I agree with what seem to be obvious omissions. But heck, why stop here. Get The Beatles 1962-1966 and 1967-1970 (The Red and Blue Albums) for more great music, more depth and song lyrics included. Again, this is just a starter set to whet your appetite.

0375707972|3.0|Once again, I read an \\"Oprah Pick\\" without realizing it until afterword. Anyway... this is a superficially simple novel that, for all its flaws, is worth spending a little time thinking about. The foremost thing to realize about it, is that it's main theme concerns postwar Germany's grappling with the legacy of the Holocaust. It's about those who were adults during the war, and the next generation. It's about how that younger generation (of which Schlink is certainly a member) reacted to the generation and individuals who participated in the Holocaust.<br />Recounted in memoir form, the story begins with the tale of a 15-year-old boy and his sexual affair with a 36-year-old tram female tram conductor. The man tells of this time with a certain air of nostalgia that is somewhat understandable. And yet, if one thinks about the ages of the two people, it's also horrific. Make the boy a girl, and make the conductor a man, the psychological dynamic becomes rather clear. This is a problematic element in the novel, and one that is never dealt with in any way.<br />Years after their affair had ended, the now young man discovers that his older lover was a concentration camp guard and was involved in an incident in which a number of prisoners were locked inside a burning church. The twist in the matter is that she fails to properly defend herself of the charges of being the ringleader in the incident because she is secretly illiterate. Clearly the author isn't trying to excuse her war crimes in any way, or imply that she's somehow not really at fault. In prison she learns to read and studies the Holocaust in great deal, and importantly, decides that there is no redemption or atonement available for what she did.<br />But does the author mean this to apply to all Nazis? Or just those who fell into it? And what precisely does that mean? And, and important, but unexplored point, why does he chose to mention at the very beginning that she is Romanian, and never again? So, plenty to think about and discuss. I found the writing to be very precise and clean, an apparently excellent translation, although others' tastes may vary. Someone should translate and publish his crime novels.o think about and discuss. I found the writing to be very precise and clean, an apparently excellent translation, although others' tastes may vary. Someone should translate and publish his crime novels.

B00005OAIE|3.0|From the moment I heard of the name John Mayer, I was expected by one of my closest friends to cherish his music and hold his name in equation with great music. I used a free coupon I had for my BMG music membership to order the album \\"Room for Squares\\". I received it a week or so later and proceeded to sit in my room, uninterrupted, listening to his music. The first song gripped me right off the bat. It felt true. The lyrics were, in a word, perfect. They agreed with my perceptions of the high school I had graduated just a year previous. I fricking hated that place and everything it represented. I wasn't part of the prom king community nor did I take kindly to being spoken to in a condescending way. I identified with the song and hold it in high regard to this day. That song is \\"No Such Thing.\\"<br />The second song on the album made my heart sink. It demonstrated a lack of true musical talent. The music for that song, \\"Georgia\\", wasn't nearly as intricate or involving as that for \\"No Such Thing.\\" Also, I picked up on a certain urgency on John Mayer's part to cram too many words into the melody. The words, how they were sang, and how they flowed, didn't mesh with the music.<br />This was only the beginning of my disappointment. My faith was temporarily renewed when I listened to \\"Neon,\\" which seemed to demonstrate the same kind of mastery over melody and lyric that \\"No Such Thing\\" had. The rest of the album shared the same downward spiral pattern of \\"Georgia.\\" And \\"Your Body is a Wonderland\\" made me smack my head. This was a deliberate attempt to get on the good side of easily manipulated teenage girls who were just growing out of the Spears-Aguilera phase, and with boy bands like Backstreet Boys and N'Sync pretty much out of the picture, Mayer is the perfect transference device for that baseless adoration.<br />I began to wonder as I looked through the liner notes for the CD exactly what it was I was picking up on. Such wonderful songs were \\"No Such Thing,\\" \\"Neon,\\" and even \\"Love Song for No One\\", and such great poetry was the album as a whole, but why were the remaining songs on the disc so devoid of true musical feeling? Then I saw it: the lyrics of \\"No Such Thing,\\" \\"Neon,\\" and \\"Love Song for No One\\" were set to the music John Mayer had written with a partner (Clay Cook). This was my answer. Mayer pretty much fails as a composer. The music he writes himself is too simple to be combined with such poetic, complicated lyrics. On the whole, I respect John Mayer's ability as a lyricist. But I think he would've been better off as the coffee house poet who occasionally strums his guitar to accent certain stanzas. His talent on this album is evident, but it is not nearly that which merits a Best New Artist Grammy, or any Grammy whatsoever. This is a musician who has a lot to work on before he can achieve the true greatness many young people feel he has already achieved.<br />I give this album an overall positive rating because of Mayer's lyrical talents and for the feat of getting two great songs on one album (something not easily done), but make no mistake: \\"Room for Squares\\" definitely has room for improvement.and even \\"Love Song for No One\\", and such great poetry was the album as a whole, but why were the remaining songs on the disc so devoid of true musical feeling? Then I saw it: the lyrics of \\"No Such Thing,\\" \\"Neon,\\" and \\"Love Song for No One\\" were set to the music John Mayer had written with a partner (Clay Cook). This was my answer. Mayer pretty much fails as a composer. The music he writes himself is too simple to be combined with such poetic, complicated lyrics. On the whole, I respect John Mayer's ability as a lyricist. But I think he would've been better off as the coffee house poet who occasionally strums his guitar to accent certain stanzas. His talent on this album is evident, but it is not nearly that which merits a Best New Artist Grammy, or any Grammy whatsoever. This is a musician who has a lot to work on before he can achieve the true greatness many young people feel he has already achieved.<br />I give this album an overall positive rating because of Mayer's lyrical talents and for the feat of getting two great songs on one album (something not easily done), but make no mistake: \\"Room for Squares\\" definitely has room for improvement.

B00006AW2M|4.0|This album does have some great moments on it, although it's not too many people's favourite Stones' albums.  It was recorded in the midst of Mick, Keith and Brian's infamous drug busts.  This album features one of their sweetest ballads \\"She's a Rainbow\\" (at least until the violins screech a rather eerie coda with an abrasive guitar riff to follow), which helped sell a few gaudy looking computers in the 1990's.  \\"2000 Light Years From Home\\" was supposedly contrived from the alienation Mick felt during the infamous drug busts and there's a cool sounding mellotron provided by Brian and some eerie piano work from Nicky Hopkins (I think this was his debut with the Stones).  \\"Citadel\\" could fit in as part of any 1960's sci-fi soundtrack (Brian provides saxophone and probably a glockenspiel, whatever that clinking sound is at the chorus and Keith's guitar riff is a nice touch).  Bill Wyman contributes his 1st song as he sings \\"In Another Land\\" (although Bill isn't much of a singer, this song features a cool harpsicord by Nicky).  \\"2000 Man\\" is sort of a country rock meets Motown song (that's Bill snoring at the beginning).  \\"The Lantern\\" has some eerie lyrics set to a gospel-flavoured piano and some funky guitar licks.  \\"Sing This All Together\\" is a singalong which supposedly features John and Paul in the chorus.  Not as clever is \\"Sing This All Together (See What Happens)\\" as Mick moans and screams in the microphone for 5 minutes, not unlike \\"Goin' Home.\\"  Keith sounds bored playing the same chords for 5 minutes.  You can hear Mick audibly asking at the beginning \\"Where's that joint?\\"  \\"On With the Show\\" is about a sleazy pub- \\"Your wife will never know that you're not really working late!\\"  The worst song is \\"Gomper\\" with a sloppy repetitive jam ( a sitar, a Hammond organ and some self-conscious Eastern philosophy).  All in all, not a bad album but the Stones would prove on the next album Beggars Banquet that they were the World's Greatest Rock and Roll Band, not the World's Greatest Psychedellic Band.
B00005ATZT|5.0|Loosely based on the 1954 murder case of Sam Sheppard - whose son fights to clear his father's name to this day - 1960s television created an added dose of drama by allowing The Fugitive (the late David Janssen) to escape from prison, and hunt down the man who murdered his wife in cold blood.<br />Perhaps never in the history of TV was a plotline so ripe for the treatment (and budget) afforded by the big screen - and, perhaps, never has it been done so well.<br />Harrison Ford plays Doctor Richard Kimble, a Chicago-area vascular surgeon (\\"What the hell is that?\\" asks one of his pursuers. \\"Someone who makes a lot more money than you,\\" answers another in the easy, natural humor of two people who've worked together for years) who seems, at first, too good to be true. A philanthropist respected by the community, loved by his colleagues and adored by his wife, you can't help but wonder if there's trouble in paradise, despite the shadowy presence of Helen Kimble's (Sela Ward, bringing remarkable life to a dead woman, thanks to flashbacks) killer.<br />Chicago's finest quickly come to the same conclusion, and a damning 911 phone call by the dying victim seals Kimble's fate - a death sentence!<br />Fate, however, has other ideas. One of four survivors of the most spectacular - and controversial - train wreck ever captured on film, Kimble sets off to blend in to the Windy City's skyline long enough to find the man who took Helen from him. He has plenty of clues to start him on the trail; his biggest enemy not so much his pursuers as time itself.<br />Deputy United States Marshal Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones, who won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor), meantime, is as dogged as his prey; so determined to capture \\"my man\\" that, when confronted by the fugitive Kimble and his professed innocence, snaps back, \\"I don't care!\\"<br />Though Gerard isn't \\"out to solve a puzzle here,\\" Kimble is, and with equal persistence. The plot that led to the death of his wife is revealed in tense, dramatic fashion to the audience as Kimble himself learns it - and learns who has betrayed him.<br />What remains, of course, is whether his time has run out.<br />Ford's Kimble is what many people would consider an oxymoron: A truly benevolent, honest doctor. Best known as the almost-reckless Indiana Jones, Ford plays Kimble as a highly intelligent man who uses his wits and a level head to keep one step in front of not one, but two groups of adversaries.<br />Hot on Kimble's heels, Jones' Gerard does Ford one better by creating a lawman walking the thin line between pursuit and obsession. \\"Never argue with the big dog,\\" Gerard admonishes his team, when Kimble shows up \\"not dead yet\\" - proof, yet again, that \\"the big dog is always right.\\"<br />Hunter and prey, cat and mouse, Jones and Ford present real people trapped in a deadly game. The viewer quickly bonds with Kimble and roots for his success, while not quite able to root against Gerard. \\"It's alright if you catch him,\\" we seem to be saying, \\"just, not yet!\\"<br />A supporting cast including Joe Pantoliano, Jeroen Krabbe and Julianne Moore (in a small, but pivotal role) is equally up to the task; never did anyone's performance feel like they were acting, and the rich range of emotions coupled with crisp pacing, a riveting storyline and a properly brassy soundtrack adds up to one of the finest films ever made.<br />Virtually every person on Earth has seen The Fugitive; buy the DVD, and you'll never forget why.
